docs.title: 🔬 BIA Sanity Preserver 🧠
docs.text:
Because setting up bio image analysis tools shouldn’t cost you your sanity.

Setting up bio image analysis (BIA) tools the sane way is hard. Requirements change. Dependencies fight. Conflicts arise. Environments grow tangled and break.

BIA Sanity Preserver is here to restore balance.

With it, you can install and run your favourite bio image analysis tools in clean, isolated environments, avoiding conflicts and keeping your workflows reproducible and drama-free.

docs.title: 🧩 The Idea
docs.text:
In one work, use pixi. No containers, no complexity, just pure, isolated environments.

📦 Each tool gets its own dedicated environment. ⚡ Environments can be quickly created, fearlessly modified (thanks to pixi locks 🔒), and easily deleted.

docs.title: 🚀 Getting Started
docs.text:
All you need is:

  1. pixi installed → pixi
  2. This repository cloned:
git clone https://github.com/lorenzocerrone/BIA-Sanity-Preserver

That’s it. You’re officially on the path to BIA enlightenment.

docs.title: 🛠️ Tools Included
docs.text:
Run your tools with a single command and zero emotional damage:

  • Cellpose
  • Napari with OME-Zarr support
  • ilastik
  • Plant-seg
  • Feature-explorer

docs.title: 🏗️ Environments
docs.text:
Ready-to-use environments for bio image analysis:

  • Python Scientific Stack
  • Ngio

docs.title: 🤝 Contributing
docs.text:
Any contributions are welcome! Here’s how you can help:

  • If something's not working, open an issue 🐛
  • If you have ideas for new tools or improvements, open an issue 💡
  • If you want to add a tool or improve an existing setup, submit a pull request 🚀

docs.title: 🧪 Testing
docs.text: Each environment is automatically installed on Ubuntu, macOS, and Windows using GitHub Actions to ensure cross-platform compatibility. The tools themselves are not tested beyond installation.

docs.title: 🤝 Contributing
docs.text:
Such a project can only thrive with the help of the community, to make sure that it stays up-to-date and useful for everyone. Here’s how you can contribute:

  • If you have ideas for new tools or improvements, open an issue 💡
  • If you test some tools, and had an issue let us know by opening an issue 🐛
  • If you know your way around pixi and want to add a tool or improve an existing setup, submit a pull request 🚀
  • If the documentation is lacking or unclear, feel free to suggest improvements via pull requests ✍️

docs.title: 🧪 Testing
docs.text: Each environment is automatically installed on Ubuntu, macOS, and Windows using GitHub Actions to ensure cross-platform compatibility. The tools themselves are not tested beyond installation.

docs.title: Ngio
docs.text: ngio is a Python library for working with next-generation image formats, providing efficient access to modern image storage formats. Learn more about ngio at ngio repository.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
ngio is available in the ngio environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

pixi run -e ngio YOUR_COMMAND

docs.title: Python Scientific Stack
docs.text: A comprehensive Python environment with essential libraries for bio image analysis including numpy, scipy, pandas, scikit-image, matplotlib, jupyterlab, and more. Learn more about the scientific Python ecosystem at scipy.org.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
The Python Scientific Stack is available in the bia-sci-py-stack environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

pixi run -e bia-sci-py-stack YOUR_COMMAND

docs.title: Start JupyterLab
docs.text:
Launch JupyterLab for interactive analysis:

pixi run jupyterlab

docs.title: Cellpose
docs.text: Cellpose is a generalist tool for cellular segmentation using deep learning. Lern more about Cellpose at Cellpose repository.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
Cellpose is available in the cellpose environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

pixi run -e cellpose YOUR_COMMAND

docs.title: Cellpose 2D GUI
docs.text:
Start the Cellpose graphical interface for 2D segmentation:

pixi run cellpose

docs.title: Cellpose 3D GUI
docs.text:
Start the Cellpose graphical interface for 3D segmentation:

pixi run cellpose-3D

docs.title: Feature-explorer
docs.text: Feature Explorer is a Python dashboard application for exploring OME-Zarr images alongside tabular data. Learn more about Feature Explorer at feature-explorer repository.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
Feature Explorer is available in the feature-explorer environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

pixi run -e feature-explorer YOUR_COMMAND

docs.title: Start Feature Explorer Dashboard
docs.text:
Launch the interactive Feature Explorer dashboard:

pixi run feature-explorer

docs.title: ilastik
docs.text: ilastik is an interactive machine learning toolkit for image classification and segmentation without requiring machine learning expertise. Learn more about ilastik at ilastik.org.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
ilastik is available in the ilastik environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

pixi run -e ilastik YOUR_COMMAND

docs.title: Start ilastik GUI
docs.text:
Launch the ilastik graphical user interface:

pixi run ilastik

docs.title: Napari (OME-Zarr)
docs.text: Napari is a fast, interactive, multi-dimensional image viewer for Python with OME-Zarr support for handling large datasets. Learn more about Napari at napari.org.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
Napari with OME-Zarr support is available in the napari-ome-zarr environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

pixi run -e napari-ome-zarr YOUR_COMMAND

docs.title: Start Napari
docs.text:
Launch the napari viewer with OME-Zarr support:

pixi run napari

docs.title: Environment

PlantSeg is available in the plantseg environment.

To activate the environment, pre-fix your commands with:

docs.title: Start PlantSeg GUI
docs.text:
